document.docAuthor: Alonso-Zarazaga, Miguel A. & Lyal, Christopher H. C.
document.masterDocTitle: A catalogue of family and genus group names in Scolytinae and Platypodinae with nomenclatural remarks (Coleoptera: Curculionidae) 2258

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A catalogue of family and genus group names in Scolytinae and Platypodinae with nomenclatural remarks (Coleoptera: Curculionidae) 2258

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks: This genus was originally described as incertae sedis and “placed on the debatable land between the Curculionidae and Ipidae ” (Sampson, l.c. ). Schedl (1957b-14) stated that it was neither a Scolytid nor a Platypodid. The genus is not present in any volume of the Junk Coleopterorum Catalogus , and is also omitted from Alonso-Zarazaga and Lyal (1999) .
Lawrence et al . (2000)
doubtfully placed the genus in Scolytinae , but Bright and Skidmore (2002 -161) identified the genus as “almost certainly … a Cossoninae ( Curculionidae )”. An examination of the type material reveals that there is a long hypostomal tooth (well-figured in the original description), and we consider the genus as probably a Cossoninae with a reduced tibial uncus. We place it in Cossoninae incertae sedis . Distribution: Seychelles

subSubSection.paragraph:
Note: The relationship between the Platypodinae and Scolytinae is far from agreed, and poses a problem for the cataloguer, both in terms of ranks and of content. Wood & Bright (1992) and Wood (2007) treat each as a family, distinct from the Curculionidae , as does Thompson (1992) with rather more doubt. Kuschel (1995) treats both as subfamilies of Curculionidae , whilst highlighting uncertainties about their relationships.
Kuschel et al. (2000)
propose a monophyletic Platypodini (equivalent to Platypodidae of other authors) lying within the Scolytinae , and with
Carphodicticus
,
Schedlarius
,
Mecopelmus
and
Coptonotus
as increasingly basal branches off the lineage leading to Platypodini at various points. Jordal (2007) has the same pattern, although without some Scolytinae between
Coptonotus
and the others, which is a feature of the consensus tree in
Kuschel et al. (2000)
. However, Marvaldi (1997) and
Oberprieler et al. (2007)
place the Platypodinae distant from the Scolytinae (not mentioning Carphodictini, Schedlariini, Mecopelmini and Coptonotinae ). In view of this uncertainty, and following
Oberprieler et al. (2007)
, Platypodinae and Scolytinae are treated here as separate subfamilies within the Curculionidae . Ranks of subordinate taxa have been adjusted accordingly, where necessary, from usages in alternative classifications used in the past 20 years. Several subordinate taxa are of problematic placement: Carphodictini, Schedlariini, Mecopelmini and Coptonotinae . Although there seems to be broad agreement where these taxa have been studied, there are still strong differences of opinion and we have sought to take a conservative approach, pending publication of further analyses. Consequently Mecopelmini and Schedlariini are placed in the Platypodinae and Carphodictini and Coptonotinae in the Scolytinae . This arrangement will almost certainly change in the future.

Remarks: Unavailable: no type species designated (Art. 13.3). Not recognised as unavailable in Wood and Bright (1992 -1214) and Wood (1993) , although it was declared “invalid” (meaning unavailable) by Browne (1962a-653). Bright and Skidmore (2002 -188) also erroneously stated the name to be available and valid. Replacement names are only available when the replaced name is available as well, and
Platyscapus Schedl, 1939
is unavailable, as noted above. Wood and Bright (1992 -1214) mentioned a type species designation of
Platypus carinulatus Chapuis, 1865
“automatic, subsequent designation by Wood, 1992b: 90 ”; this refers to the type species designation for
Platyscapus
mentioned above, which is not Code-compliant (see above). The same type species is cited by Beaver (2007 -18), but the genus is not made available because he does not fulfill the requirements of Art. 16.1.

subSubSection.paragraph: Remarks: Unavailable: does not meet the requirements of Art. 13.1.

Remarks: We keep the rank of this subfamily here as a tribe, as proposed by Wood (1993) and consistent with the findings of
Kuschel et al. (2000)
. Jordal (2007 -8) considers that this is a basal branch in the phylogeny of the core Platypodinae , and we are here transferring Mecopelmini from Coptonotinae to Platypodinae , in agreement with Thompson (1992) . See also Notes under Coptonotini .
Remarks: 1 sp. Transferred from Coptonotidae to Platypodidae Mecopelminae by Thompson (1992 - 882). See discussion under Mecopelmini, above.

Remarks: A replacement name for Chapuisides [sic!] Blandford, 1895, incorrectly spelled. The correct spelling should be Schedlariini. The first instance of the name (as Schedlarini ) is in Wood and Bright ( l.c. ), not Wood (1957 -103). Wood and Bright ( l.c. ) refer to the name as an “automatic replacement”; certainly according to Art. 30 the new family-group name should be based on the replacement name of the genus (if, as here, no alternative junior synonym is available), but no proposal was made by Wood (1957) .
Remarks: A corrected spelling. We also transfer the tribe here from Coptonotinae to Platypodinae .

Remarks: Wood and Bright (1992 -321) stated: “Nomen nudum, no status (originally presented as a species group name, no generic standing)”, repeating the opinion of Wood (1986-59). However, whilst Wood (1986-59) stated that it was “not a genus-group name, no status” he designated a type species, contradicting himself. Under Art. 10.4 the name is available as a section inside a subgenus. However, it is an invalid objective synonym of
Scolytochelus Reitter.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks: Thompson (1992 -886) moved the Carphodicticini from Scolytinae to Platypodidae as a subfamily. Later,
Kuschel et al. (2000
-784) transferred it from Coptonotinae (although it had not been placed here) to Scolytinae , and placed it near but not inside Platypodini (l.c., p. 785). Jordal (2007 -8) placed
Carphodicticus
as the penultimate outer branch in the phylogeny of core Platypodinae , just outside of
Schedlarius
and
Mecopelmus
and inside of
Coptonotus
. However, as discussed under ‘Platypodinae’ above,
Oberprieler et al (2007)
and Marvaldi (1997) place the Platypodinae distant from the Scolytinae , not mentioning Carphodictini and groups of similar placement. In view of this uncertainty, coupled with the observation that Carphodictini lack many of the apomorphies associated with Platypodinae and more resemble Scolytinae auctt. , and the placement of Carphodictini within Scolytinae in Wood and Bright (1992) , we are retaining the tribe within the Scolytinae here.
Distribution: India , Sri Lanka , Vietnam , Borneo
Remarks: 1 sp. Wood (2007 -333) writes the type species name incorrectly as argentinae . Distribution: Argentina

bibRefCitation.author: Chapuis, F. & Synopsis des Scolytides

subSubSection.paragraph:
Note: In Wood and Bright’s (1992-1084) systematics, their subfamily Coptonotinae included three tribes ( Coptonotini , Mecopelmini and Schedlarini [sic!]) in the family Platypodidae . The first tribe included, apart from the type genus, two other genera:
Protohylastes Wood, 1973
and
Scolytotarsus Schedl, 1937
.
Protohylastes
was placed in synonymy with
Psepholax White, 1843
( Curculionidae : Cryptorhynchinae: Psepholacini ) by Zimmerman (1994 -644); Bright and Skidmore (1997) did not record the change, but the synonymy was recorded in Alonso-Zarazaga and Lyal (1999) , although
Kuschel et al. (2000)
referred to the genera as “close relatives”.
Scolytotarsus Schedl
was placed as a valid genus in Curculionidae ( Conoderinae : Campyloscelini: Phaenomerina) by Voss (1962 -279), in which he was followed by Alonso-Zarazaga and Lyal (1999) . The second tribe included the genus
Protoplatypus Wood, 1973
; this was moved from Platypodidae to Cossoninae by Zimmerman (1994 -644) and subsequently to Cossoninae : Rhyncolini by Kuschel (1995 -25), although the placement was unrecognized in Bright and Skidmore (1997) . Alonso-Zarazaga and Lyal (1999 -122) placed the genus in Curculionidae ( Cossoninae : Rhyncolini : Rhyncolina ).
Kuschel et al. (2000)
found that
Protoplatypus
fell within the
Cossonus
-group of genera in their analysis. As discussed under Platypodinae above, we are retaining Coptonotini within the Scolytinae in this catalogue, although sensible that this position may need to change following future analyses.

Remarks: 2 spp. Transferred to Scolytinae near Hylesinini by Thompson (1992 -882).
Kuschel et al. (2000
-784) also transferred the genus from Coptonotinae to Scolytinae , overlooking Thompson’s previous placement but rejecting Wood and Bright’s (1992-1084) and Wood’s (1993) placement.
Distribution: Costa Rica , Panama ; Colombia , French Guiana , Peru , Suriname

Remarks: 21 spp. Wood (2007) commented in the original description of
Corthyloxiphus
(p. 788): “a replacement name for
Corthycyclon Schedl (1951: 128)
when the type-species,
Corthycyclon ustum Schedl
, was transferred to
Corthylus
(see
Corthycyclon
in Wood & Bright c1992: 1067-1068 for references to included species)”. However,
Corthycyclon Schedl, 1951
[synonymized with
Corthylus
by Wood (2007 -804)] has a type by monotypy, which is
C. ustum
. Consequently Wood is simply describing a new genus for the species previous included in
Corthycyclon
that he finds are not congeneric with the type species, which he places in
Corthylus
. Replacement names are only to replace available names, and “
Corthycyclon
minus its type species” is not such a name. Consequently
Corthyloxiphus
is simply a new genus in Wood (2007) .
Distribution: Mexico ; Costa Rica , Panama ; Bolivia , Colombia , Peru , Venezuela

Pseudocryphalus
was originally a “Section” in

combination “
Pseudocryphalus sidneyanus Ferrari
”, used by Wood (1986-91) with the date ‘1969’ and Wood and Bright (1992 -872) (with the reference “1868b” rather than “1868” to match their bibliography), is not present. In the list of species they ( Wood & Bright, 1992 -894) only quoted
Bostrichus sidneyanus Nordlinger
[sic!], 1856 stating below: “Also cited under the generic name
Pseudocryphalus
” but without providing a reference. Curiously enough, Wood (1986-91) had already cited correctly “
Bostrichus sidneyanus Nordlinger
[sic!], Monobasic”.

Remarks: The genus originally contained 2 species:

and

subsequently designated
Bostrichus piceae Ratzeburg
as type for the first time. Wood (1954 -988) recognised the same species as the type . Later, Wood (1986-91) cited
Bostrichus abietis
as type species by OD, without further comment, while Wood and Bright (1992 -872) cited the same species as the type by M, without further clarification of this change.

This does not make this genus available as a combined description since, according to Art. 13.4, after 1930 such a provision only serves to make the names available if there is a single new species, and the description necessary to make the generic name available (Art. 13.1.1) is not present. Remarks: 6 spp. The original gender is not clear at first sight since the type (and single) species has no inflected ending. It is derived from the Greek adjective trischides , “cut in three”, with an ending change to turn it into a masculine noun (cf. Buck & Petersen, 1945 -170). Incorrectly used as feminine by Wood (1954 -1066), Wood and Bright (1992 -947), Bright and Skidmore (1997 -197) and Wood (2007 -526). The following gender agreements must be modified:
T. exiguus Wood, 1986
,
T. minutissimus Wood, 1954
,
T. spinatus (Schedl, 1977)
and
T. striatus Atkinson, 1993
.
T. atomus (Hopkins, 1915)
, being an invariable noun in apposition, must not be corrected.

Remarks: 106 spp. Originally an emendation of

by Strohmeyer himself (1911a-16). This author did not give any reason for the emendation: “Der Anfangsbuchstabe des Names
Kyrtogenius
im Jahrg. 1910 der Ent. Blätter, p. 127, ist in C zu ändern”. Hopkins (1914 -120) stated that this name is an emendation for
Kyrtogenius
. The reference in Neave (1939a-949):
“ Cyrtogenius
(err. pro Kyr - Strohmeyer 1910) Eggers, 1927, Rev.zool.afric.15, 197”, is just a later use. The reference “1910e: 217” given by Wood and Bright (1992 -562) is the original for the replaced name. As far as we know, the spelling
Kyrtogenius
was used only in the original description as valid, while
Cyrtogenius
is in predominant usage since 1911. We here apply Art. 33.2.3.1 of the Code.

Remarks: 186 + 2 (+) spp. Wood (2007 -249) incorrectly states that the gender is to be considered as feminine, based on a non-cited source. However, Art. 30.1.4.4 of the Code states that “A compound genus-group name ending in the suffix - ites , - oides , - ides , - odes , or - istes is to be treated as masculine unless its author, when establishing the name, stated that it had another gender or treated it as such by combining it with an adjectival species-group name in another gender form”. In this case, the single species originally combined by Ferrari is
laevigatus
, a masculine past participle, and this renders the genus masculine in gender. Consequently, all the following agreements must be modified (in the same order as in Wood’s treatment in text):

Wood (2007 -249) rejects the name
Scolytodes grandis (Schedl)
. He refers to the holotype of
Hexacolus grandis Schedl, 1978
as a “teratological” specimen and thus rejects the name, citing “Art 1 para B, Item 2” (equivalent to the current Art. 1.3.2 of the Code). However, the name was proposed for a species, not for a teratology, and the specimen is not in any case teratological but a “composite” specimen (i.e. a ‘chimaera’); in both cases, the Code is to be applied. As the specimen is a composite Art 73.1.5 applies, and components need to be excluded until a single species is represented, and a unique synonymy established. Currently, because of the uncertainty of the identity of any of the three species involved, such a synonymy cannot be made.

Remarks: 40 spp. Wood (1978 -111), Wood (1986-39) and Wood and Bright (1992 -96) placed this genus in synonymy under

( l.c. , p. 94), where it still stands. Consequently, we are compelled to reinstate

as the valid name for the genus
Hylesinopsis
, following the systematic arrangement proposed by Wood and Bright. The genus is clearly not monophyletic in its present limits (R.A. Beaver, pers. comm. ) and it is the subject of ongoing research. New combinations (all from

Remarks: Wood and Bright (1992 -103) gave as origin of this nominal taxon “ Barbey 1901 -19”, but it does not occur in this publication. Wood (1978 -111, 1982-129, 1986-40) correctly quoted Nuesslin, 1912 -273, and Wood and Bright again “Nusslin [sic!] 1912:273” in the text (in their bibliography it is present as “1912c”).

Remarks: Although Wood ( l.c.) gave Thomson (1859) as author, Thomson’s usage was with the type genus in its concept as =
Ips
, whilst Wood (1978) used it in the concept of =
Blastophagus
. Consequently Wood, perhaps inadvertently, proposed a new taxon (
Tomicini Wood, 1978
non Thomson, 1859 ). We recognize this here, even though it is a junior subjective synonym.

The situation is discussed in some detail above under the chapter “Problematic actions”. We plan to include the matter of
Tomicini
Wood, 1978
in our application to the Commission, since in our opinion its continuation as an available name will jeopardise stability. A family-group name based on a misidentified type genus would seem to be an available name; the problems caused are not covered in the Code.

Remarks: 2 spp. Wood and Bright (1992 -105) and Wood (2007 -50) gave an erroneous reference “1922-433” in the text; according to their bibliography this should be “1921a-433”, but examination of the cover of the original volume shows that this paper should be dated 1923. Wood (2007 -53,k and 57) apparently transfers
S. porteri Brèthes, 1923
to
Xylechinus
, whilst leaving a second species,
S. destructor Eggers
, alone in
Sinophloeus
. This species was treated as a junior synonym of
S. porteri
by Wood and Bright (1992 -105), and the discussion of it by Wood (2007 -51) refers to
S. porteri
and reads as though Wood considers
S. porteri
and
S. desctuctor
to be the same. The heading for
porteri
in
Xylechinus
is “
Sinophloeus porteri Brèthes
”. Wood (2007 -57) also synonymises
Xylechinus spathifer
with
S. porteri
, despite on p. 51 referring to this as a ‘second, much smaller species’. Moreover,
S. porteri Brèthes, 1923
is still referred to as type of
Sinophloeus .
Finally, Brèthes’ (1923) image of
S. porteri
’s antenna shows seven segments in the funicle, as in the description; if this is the case the species cannot fit into
Xylechinus
as described by Wood (2007 -51), which is characterised by only five segments in the funicle. Clearly there are problems with the apparent situation, and it seems likely that there is a printer’s error involved. We are assuming that
Sinophloeus
stands, with the type species
S. porteri Brèthes, 1923
. As a further complication there is another species named “
Sinophloeus porteri Brèthes
” by Wood (2007 -60) (which would be a junior homonym of
S. porteri Brèthes, 1923
); however, this has never been in
Sinophloeus
since Brèthes (1925 -202) originally described it in
Xylechinus .
A printer’s error is inferred for this also. The type species designation of
Sinophloeus
was incorrectly given as M. This situation will be further clarified in a forthcoming paper.

=

-288) used

, but placed

(the type species of
Tomicus
, q.v) under

in Hylesinidae, so in fact he was misidentifying the genus for

. This is the concept followed by C.G. Thomson (1859 -145) that Wood and Bright (1992 -103) considered erroneously to be identical to the tribe here named

(q.v). Moreover, they erroneously gave as author and date for this familygroup name C.G. Thomson (1859) , overlooking the use by Shuckard (1840) .

(i.e. =
Ips

typographus Linnaeus
as type species for the genus. Wood and Bright (1992 -103) used this as an available family-group name (ranked as a tribe (cf.

Remarks: Unavailable: does not meet the requirements of Art. 11.7.1.1. The original concept was not clear, Kolbe including
Diamerus
,
Xylocleptes
,
Premnobius
and
Xyleborus
, but making no mention of
Tomicus
and its concept. The same spelling was also present in Trédl (1907c-41), based on the misidentified concept of the genus
Tomicus .
Wood and Bright (1992 -103 & 438, under Tomicini and Ipini ) gave Hagedorn (1908 -375) as the source for this spelling, overlooking the earlier use by Kolbe ( l.c.) .

Remarks: The oldest spelling for this record is given by Wood and Bright (1992 -28) from “Nusslin [sic!], 1882”. If true, this should have precedence over that of Bedel (1888 , see above). We have checked Nuesslin’s (1882) paper, but failed to find this spelling. The second reference in chronological order given by Wood and Bright (1992 -28) is “Escherich 1897: 229-239”, which does not agree any reference given for this author in their bibliography. Consequently, we assign this spelling to the first author we have been able to find as using this spelling, corresponding to Wood and Bright’s (1992-28) erroneous reference “Ganglbauer, 1902: 311”, correctly given as “1903” in Wood & Bright (1987 -213).
Remarks: The reference to Reitter (1895 -39, erroneously dated as “1894a”) in Wood and Bright (1992 -438) is incorrect; moreover the spelling is given as Ipini .
Remarks: Wood and Bright (1992 -438) cite Balachowsky (1949 -253) erroneously as the source for this spelling, overlooking Reitter (1913) .
Remarks: Not present in Wood and Bright (1992 -438).
Remarks: Wood and Bright (1992 -438) cite as a source for this name “ Balachowsky 1947 -44”, but it is not present in that publication.

Note: It is incomprehensible why Wood and Bright (1992 -103), recognising that the concept of the type genus supporting Tomicidae C.G. Thomson, 1859 was a misidentification, kept this name as valid for a tribe in Scolytidae . This has simply prolonged the confusion that has reigned over more than one hundred years into the 21 st century. We have placed the references where they should stand and qualified them as accurately as possible. In our opinion, no family-group name based on
Tomicus
(no matter the sense) can be used according to the Code (see above) and continuation in its use is a source of confusion.

Remarks: Fabricius did not mention any author for the genus he was using, so there must be doubt whether he was using Geoffroy’s genus, in which case this would be just a later use. We conclude it was a newly proposed genus, and select one of the originally included species as its type species. It is, however, well known that Fabricius used others’ generic names in quite different senses based on his “authority”.

by Neave (1939a-455), whom we follow here.

Remarks:. The single species included in his genus by Latreille in this work was
Dermestes typographus Linnaeus, 1758
, while Latreille (1810 -431) gave as the type species
Bostrychus typographus Fabricius
(actually the same species as
D. typographus Linnaeus
). Latreille’s original use of
Tomicus
was with
Dermestes piniperda Linnaeus
as type , and this change of concept has produced much confusion, affecting even the naming of the family-group taxa. This is discussed in full under
Tomicus Latreille, 1802
above. We will be requesting the Commission to suppress
Tomicus Latreille, 1806
-276.

Remarks: 10 spp. Originally as a subgenus of
Ips
, no indication on gender. Apparently the last part of the generic name is derived from a verb, kteín ō, meaning “to kill”, to the stem of which a substantival ending in - es has been added. Consequently, if we apply Art. 30.1.3 of the Code, an ending in - es would be a Latin 3rd declension masculine or feminine name, which would lead to the application of Art. 30.1.4.2, which determines its gender as masculine.

Remarks: 27 spp. Originally the description had no mention of etymology (and the author did not even cite it as a good genus, unlike
Chramesus
and
Cnesinus
). However, there is an etymological problem. The genus name is derived from the Greek words mikrós (small) and akís (point), probably referring to the acuminate elytral apex (Beaver and Jordal pers. comm. ), since the family-group name based on it (Micracides) shows a stem micracid- and the usual ending in -es that LeConte used for groups below tribe (cf. Hylastes on p. 387). LeConte formed the stem correctly, since the genitive form of akís is akíd-os . However, LeConte (1868) incorrectly used his genus as masculine and provided a confused use of masculine (
hirtellus
) and feminine (
aculeata, nanula
) in 1876 (p. 368-9). The actual gender of akís is feminine (corrected above). Later authors seem to have supposed that the second part is the commonly used Greek word kís (woodboring worm) in Scolytinae and that LeConte incorrectly used an -a- instead of an -o- as a linking vowel. This would have matched the originally selected masculine gender, but the genitive of kís is ki-ós (cf. the family name Ciidae ) and LeConte should then have spelled the family-group name as Micracies (rendered incorrectly by LeConte & Horn, 1883 -519 as Micraces). We have corrected the family-group name above. Valid species names in current catalogues needing a mandatory change due to gender agreement include:
Micracis carinulata Wood, 1960
,
M. detenta Wood, 1969
,
M. festiva Wood, 1969
,
M. incerta Wood, 1971
,
M. lepida Wood, 1969
,
M. ovata Wood, 1956
,
M. senta Wood, 1971
and
M. tribulata Wood, 1969
. Nouns in apposition or incorrect latinizations that cannot be corrected and are to be treated as invariable are:
Micracis amplinis Wood, 1971
,
M. carinulus Wood, 1969
and
M. lignicolus Wood, 1969
.
Distribution: Canada , USA , Mexico ; Costa Rica , Guatemala , Honduras , Panama ; Cuba ; Brazil , Colombia , Venezuela
Distribution: USA , Mexico ; Guatemala , Honduras ; Bahamas ; Colombia

We have been unable to find any other designation before that of Wood, which is accepted here. For an explanation on the gender change, see under

Remarks: 24 spp. This name does not have precedence over
Holonthogaster Gemminger & Harold, 1872
. However, we will be applying to the Commission to declare the latter name a nomen oblitum (see below), and
Hyledius
a nomen protectum . Although
Holonthogaster
is not in use, we have been unable to locate 25 published uses of
Hyledius
as a valid name. The 13 appearances in text so far located are Beaver (1995 , 1998b ), Beeson (1941 , 1961 ), Schedl, (1958d), Bright (1989) , Bright and Skidmore (1997 , 2002 ), Hulcr et al. (2007), Sampson (1921) , Wood (1988 , 2007 ), Wood and Bright (1992) .
Distribution: China ; India , Sri Lanka , Burma , Thailand , Laos , Vietnam , Peninsular Malaysia , Singapore , Borneo, Sumatra, Philippines , New Guinea , Solomon Is.

Remarks: An unjustified emendation of
Olonthogaster
, which keeps its own authorship and date (Art. 33.2.3), and which has precedence over
Hyledius Sampson. Wood (1974c)
neglected to include this name in his request for suppression of
Olonthogaster
. Bright (1989 -79) stated that this name is “not actually a synonym since this name merely reflects a difference in transliterating the original Greek”, applying incorrectly the rules for unjustified emendations in the Code. However, the name has not been used in the 20 th century (Lucas, 1920a-331 used it as an invalid synonym of
Olonthogaster
), and we wish to declare it a nomen oblitum.

Remarks: The type species epithet has been changed to feminine to meet the mandatory requirements of Art. 31.2. The type species has been regarded as a (secondary) homonym of
Phloeosinus armatus Reitter, 1887
(Browne, 1963a-53; Wood & Bright, 1992 -261) and has been replaced with
Phloeosinus spinifer Browne, 1963
. However, according to Art. 59.4, the original name must stand, since the two species are now placed in different genera and there is no longer secondary homonymy. This is in accordance with article 59.4 of the Code (as 59(d) in the former edition of the Code (3rd Edition, 1985)) but this was disregarded by Wood and Bright (1992 -259, 261). The correct name of the species, therefore, is
Hyledius armatus (Schedl, 1936)
, as recognised by Beaver (1998b-185), and recorded by Bright and Skidmore (2002) .
Remarks: 1 sp. There is no monotypy, as was stated by Bright and Skidmore (1997 -57).
Distribution: India , Sri Lanka , Peninsular Malaysia , Java

=

Remarks: 4 spp. The name was not recognised as available by Wood and Bright (1992 -236). They also considered this genus erroneously as masculine. However the last part of the name is an incorrectly rendered Latinised form of the Greek feminine adjective dytiké (that likes to penetrate); the changed ending ‘-a’ makes it a Latin 1st declension feminine substantive (Art. 30.1.3). Consequently two of the included species must be correctly written as
Phloeoditica curta
and
P. setosa
.
Distribution: Andaman, Burma , India , Sri Lanka , Philippines , Vietnam

Remarks: Available according to the requirements of Art. 13.1.2, since there is a citation of a previously published discussion of the distinguishing characters ( Browne, 1961 ). Not present in Wood and Bright (1992 -651).

Remarks: 26 spp. The long comment by Wood and Bright (1992 -651) under “Notes” justifying why junior secondary homonyms created on the synonymy of
Premnobius
with
Xyleborus
should not be replaced with new names is not necessary under a careful consideration of the Code. The Code must be applied case by case, without exceptions. However, Art. 59.3 of the current Code suggests that the names, now in current use within
Premnobius
, can be used as valid. We here place this genus in its own tribe following Normark et al. ’s (1999), Beaver’s (2005 -117) and Bright and Torres’ (2006) comments and also the fact that Hulcr et al . (2007) did not include it in Xyleborini and used it as an outgroup for the cladistic analysis of this tribe.

Distribution: USA (I), Mexico (I); Costa Rica (I), Honduras (I); Bahamas (I), Cuba (I), Dominica (I), Guadeloupe(I), Jamaica (I), Puerto Rico (I), Trinidad (I); Bolivia (I), Brazil (I), Colombia (I), French Guiana(I), Guyana (I), Suriname (I), Venezuela (I); Canary Is.; Angola , Burundi , Cameroon , Congo, Equatorial Guinea , Ethiopia , Gabon , Ghana , Guinea , Ivory Coast , Kenya , Liberia , Madagascar , Malawi , Mauritania , Mozambique , Namibia , Nigeria , Ruanda , Senegal , Sierra Leone , Somalia , S Africa, Tanzania , Togo , Uganda , Urundi , Zaire, Zambia , Zimbabwe

and

is not an originally Latin or Greek word, and there are a number of species of economic importance with names having masculine endings, we are invoking Art 30.2.3. and confirming it to be masculine.

by Wood (1983 -650) and Wood and Bright (1992 - 829); reinstated as genus by Hulcr et al. (2007-580). The reference to “1961a” in Wood and Bright (1992 -829) is a dating error. Gender agreement needs to be corrected for
P. curvata (Browne, 1986)
. Distribution: Vietnam , Borneo, Sumatra, New Guinea .
Remarks: Unavailable: no type species designated (Art. 13.3).
Distribution: Mexico ; Costa Rica , Honduras , Panama ; Trinidad ; Bolivia , Brazil , Colombia , French Guiana, Peru , Venezuela

Remarks: Originally Eggers ( l.c.) simply stated “
Sampsonius sexdentatus
n.sp. ”, noting that he describes the genus elsewhere. Following Art. 13.1.1, the genus is not available because there is no generic description, and the lack of a statement “gen. nov.” means that it cannot be made available using Art. 13.4.
Distribution: Vietnam , Peninsular Malaysia , Borneo, Sumatra, Philippines ; New Guinea

Remarks: 14 spp. Treated as a synonym of
Coptoborus
by Wood (1980 -96) and Wood and Bright (1992 -662); reinstated as genus by Hulcr et al. (2007-580), but Wood (2007 -390) keeps in synonymy of
Coptoborus
.

Distribution: Peninsular Malaysia , Borneo, Sumatra, Java, Philippines , New Guinea ; Samoa ; Angola , Congo , Equatorial Guinea , Gabon , Ghana , Guinea , Ivory Coast , Nigeria , Tanzania , Uganda , Zaire , Zambia , Zimbabwe .

Remarks: 4 spp. Not a monophyletic genus, its type species has been associated with
Coptodryas
in the phylogenetic analysis of Hulcr et al. (2007).
Distribution: Peninsular Malaysia , Borneo, Java, Sumatra, New Guinea
Distribution: Mexico ; Costa Rica , Guatemala , Panama ; Trinidad ; Brazil , Colombia , French Guiana, Guyana , Suriname , Venezuela
Remarks: 10 spp. Recorded as a polyphyletic genus by Hulcr et al. (2007).

Distribution: USA , Mexico ; Costa Rica , Guatemala , Honduras , Panama ; Barbados , Dominica , Dominican Rep., Guadeloupe, Jamaica , Trinidad ; Argentina , Bolivia , Brazil , Colombia , French Guiana, Peru , Venezuela ; Cameroon (I), Equatorial Guinea (I), Ghana (I), Ivory Coast (I), Nigeria , São Tomé (I), Uganda (I), Zaire(I)

Remarks: 39 spp. Recorded as a polyphyletic genus by Hulcr et al. (2007). Incorrectly treated as masculine in Wood and Bright (1992 -829) and in Bright and Skidmore (1997 -176; 2002-126); the originally-intended gender cannot be ascertained from the single included species, so it is feminine (Art. 30.2.4 of the Code); the fact that is was named for a man rather than a woman does not provide a reason for treating the name as masculine. Limits of genus according to Hulcr et al. (2007). Gender agreements of valid species in current catalogues need to be corrected as follows:
Webbia acuta (Schedl, 1975)
,
W. bituberculata Browne, 1977
,
W. circumcisa Schedl, 1975
,
W. cornuta Schedl, 1942
,
W. costulata Schedl, 1953
,
W. cylindrica Schedl, 1942
,
W. dasyura Browne, 1981
,
W. dentata Eggers, 1927
,
W. denticulata Browne, 1983
,
W. duodecimspinata Schedl, 1942
,
W. mucronata Eggers, 1927
,
W. multidentata Browne, 1984
,
W. obtusispinosa Schedl, 1939
,
W. quadricincta Schedl, 1972
,
W. quattuordecimspinata Sampson, 1921
,
W. talaurica ( Eggers, 1923 )
,
W. trigintispinata Sampson, 1922
and
W. turbinata Maiti & Saha, 1986
. A peculiar case is given with the correct Latinization of the synonym
Webbia 26- spinatus
[sic!] Sampson, 1922 of
W. trigintispinata : Bright & Skidmore (1997
-177) created, following the dispositions of the Code,
W. duodevigintispinatus
, which must be considered an incorrect subsequent spelling, since “duodeviginti” is Latin for 18, not for 26. In classical Latin, 26 was “sex et viginti”, but the usual zoological (post-classical) rendering of this number is “vigintisex”; so we propose the latinization of this synonym as
W. vigintisexspinata
.
Distribution: Tibet , China ; Andaman, India , Sri Lanka , Burma , Thailand , Cambodia , Vietnam , Peninsular Malaysia , Borneo, Philippines ; New Guinea

Remarks. Considered erroneously a nomen nudum by Wood and Bright (1992 -829). Wood (1986-84) also considered it as a nomen nudum and referred to Browne (1963a-57) as providing the available description, but this is an error. The original description gave a character (antennal funicle 3-jointed) for genus separation from
Webbia
and
Xyleboricus
, and mentioned the generic description as appearing elsewhere; this is sufficient to provide a description. Browne (1963a-57) stated that there is a sufficient generic description and is available, he made
Webbia
=
Xelyborus
syn.n. ; he used it before as valid ( Browne, 1955 -348).
Remarks: 78 + 1 (+) spp. Recorded as a polyphyletic genus by Hulcr et al. (2007).

Distribution: Canada , USA , Mexico ; Cocos I., Costa Rica , El Salvador , Guatemala , Panama ; Cuba , Dominica , Guadeloupe, Jamaica (I); Argentina , Brazil , Chile , Colombia , Ecuador , French Guiana, Galapagos , Guyana , Paraguay , Suriname , Venezuela ; Albania , Austria , Azores, Belgium , Bulgaria , Corsica , Czechoslovakia , Denmark , England , France , Germany , Greece , Hungary , Italy , Luxemburg , Netherlands , Norway , Poland , Portugal , Romania , Russia , Sardinia, Spain , Sweden , Switzerland , Yugoslavia ; Canary Is., Madeira, Morocco , Algeria , Tunisia , Libya , Egypt , Israel , Iran , Syria , Turkey ; Japan , Siberia, China , Ryukyu, Korea , Bonin Is., Tibet, Taiwan , Sakhalin; Andaman, Nicobar, India , Sri Lanka , Bangladesh , Nepal , Burma , Thailand , Vietnam , Peninsular Malaysia , Borneo, Java, Sumatra, Philippines , Timor; New Guinea , Australia , New Zealand , Fiji , Samoa , Bismarck Is., Guam , Marianas, Palau , Society Is., Solomon Is., Cook Is., New Britain, Niue I., Hawaii; Angola , Botswana , Cameroon , Comoros , Congo , Equatorial Guinea , Gabon , Ghana , Guinea , Ivory Coast , Kenya , Liberia , Madagascar , Mozambique , Namibia , Nigeria , St Helena, Seychelles , Somalia , S Africa, Tanzania , Zaire , Zambia , Zimbabwe ; Madagascar (Copal)

Remarks: 523 + 3 (+) spp.
Xyleborus Bowdich, 1825
, was suppressed and
Xyleborus Eichhoff
was placed on the Official List of Available Genus-Group Names in Zoology (ICZN, 1968-18); type species placed on the Official List of Available Specific Names in Zoology. Wood (1974a) also applied for conservation against
Phloeotrogus
. In its present limits (according to Hulcr et al ., 2007), most likely a polyphyletic genus.

M;
Xyleborus guanajuatensis Dugès, 1888
=
Bostrichus volvulus Fabricius, 1775
; M
Remarks: Type species incorrectly given as guanaguatensis in Wood and Bright (1992 -782), as was the date.

M;
Progenius fleutiauxi Blandford, 1896
=
Xyleborus subcostatus Eichhoff, 1869
; SD : Hopkins, 1914 -128

Remarks: Type species incorrectly named
A. inurbanus
in the original description, since
Apate
is feminine in gender. Neither the original spelling nor the true date were given in Wood and Bright (1992 -818), who used
Mesoscolytus inurbanus Broun, 1904
.

N;
Boroxylon stephegynis Hopkins, 1915
=
Phloeotrogus bidentatus Motschulsky, 1863
; M Remarks: Wood and Bright (1992 -704) incorrectly cited OD as the type species designation.
Remarks: Wood and Bright (1992 -704) cited “1934” as the reference, instead of “1934d”, as is in their bibliography.

Remarks: Unavailable: no type species designated (Art. 13.3). Wood ( l.c.) proposed it as a subgenus of
Xyleborus
including four species, but none of these was designated as type species. This name is not recorded in Wood and Bright (1992 -704).

Remarks: 54 spp. The SD of
Xylosandrus germanus (Blandford)
in Browne (1963a-55) is invalid.

Distribution: Canada (I), USA , Mexico ; Costa Rica , Guatemala , Honduras , Panama (I); Cuba , Guadeloupe, Puerto Rico , Tobago , Virgin Is.; Argentina , Brazil , Colombia , French Guiana, Galapagos, Peru , Venezuela ; Austria (I), Belgium , Czechoslovakia (I), England (I), France (I), Germany (I), Italy (I), Switzerland , Yugoslavia (I); Jordan , Lebanon ; China , Japan , Korea , Tibet, Taiwan , Bonin Is., Ryukyu; Andaman, Nicobar, India , Sri Lanka , Bangladesh , Bhutan , Nepal , Burma , Thailand , Laos , Vietnam , Peninsular Malaysia , Borneo, Batoe, Java , Sumatra , Sulawesi , Soemba, Bali , Timor, Sunda Is., Moluccas , Philippines ; New Guinea , Australia , Tasmania , Fiji , Hawaii, New Zealand , Samoa , Palau , New Caledonia , Cook Is., Caroline Is., New Britain, Solomon Is., Tonga ; Cameroon , Comoros , Equatorial Guinea , Gabon , Ghana , Ivory Coast , Kenya , Liberia , Madagascar , Mauritania , Mauritius , Nigeria , Reunion, Senegal , Seychelles , Sierra Leone , S Africa, Tanzania , Uganda , Zaire

Remarks: 3 spp. Originally given as
Cryphalominus
in the genus description, and as
Cryphalomimus
in the species description. Spelling selected by Eggers (1932 -23), acting as First Reviser.
Distribution: Mozambique , S Africa, Tanzania , Zaire
Remarks: Unavailable, spelling rejected by Eggers (1932 -23), acting as First Reviser. Not present in Wood and Bright (1992 -835).
Distribution: Angola , Cameroon , Equatorial Guinea , Gabon , Ghana , Ivory Coast , Kenya , Madagascar , Namibia , Nigeria , S Africa, Tanzania , Uganda , Zaire
Distribution: Cameroon , Kenya , Malawi , Nigeria , S Africa, Tanzania , Zaire , Zambia
Remarks: There is no monotypy, as stated erroneously by Wood and Bright (1992 -835); they also cited the reference as “1967”; this should have been “1967b” as in their bibliography.
Distribution: Andaman, India , Bangladesh , Sri Lanka , Peninsular Malaysia , Borneo, Java, Philippines , New Guinea , Australia , Palau , Samoa , Fiji
Distribution: Ethiopia , Ghana , Guinea , Ivory Coast , Kenya , Madagascar , Mauritius , Mozambique , Nigeria , Ruanda , Somalia , S Africa, Sudan , Tanzania , Uganda , Zaire , Zambia

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks: Unavailable, since in Trédl’s paper the type genus
Trypodendron
is placed in synonymy of

Xyloterus
(‘partim’) and
Anisandrus
(‘ex p.’). Since it is not considered valid, it cannot be used as the basis of a family-group name according to Art. 11.7.1.1. The citation “Tredl 1907: 18” in Wood and
Bright (1992-632) refers to a reprint page and the authors erroneously consider Trédl’s paper as a single work. See bibliography entry below.
Remarks: Reference for this spelling is given as “1911: 432” by Wood and Bright (1992 -632); it should be “1911b” as in their bibliography.

Remarks: Not recognized as available by Wood and Bright (1992 -632), but is available due to the presence of a description in the key and the use of
Trypodendron
as the single included genus.
Remarks: Not present in Wood and Bright (1992 -632).
Remarks: Incorrect subsequent spelling, in synonymy, unavailable.

N;
Indocryphalus malaisei Eggers, 1939
=
Xyloterus intermedius Sampson, 1913
; OD
Distribution: Siberia, Japan , Korea , Taiwan , Sakhalin, China ; India , Nepal , Bhutan , Burma , Peninsular Malaysia

Remarks: Unavailable: no type species designated (Art. 13.3). Not recognised as unavailable by Wood and Bright (1992 -648). The type species designation of
Xyloterus aceris Niisima, 1910
by Browne, 1970 -562 (giving the original reference as a source for a description) does not make the name available, since he treated the genus as a junior synonym and the date was after 1960 (Art. 11.6).

Distribution: Alaska, Canada , USA ; Austria , Belgium , Bulgaria , Czechoslovakia , Denmark , Estonia , Finland , France , Germany , Great Britain , Greece , Hungary , Ireland , Italy , Latvia , Luxemburg , Netherlands , Norway , Poland , Romania , Russia , Sardinia, Sicily, Slovakia , Spain , Sweden , Switzerland , Yugoslavia ; Morocco , Algeria , Tunisia , Libya , Egypt , Israel , Turkey ; Siberia, Japan , Korea , China , Sakhalin, Taiwan ; Bhutan ; Wyoming (Eocene)

Remarks: This genus is considered valid by some European authors, over
Trypodendron
. Invalid (subsequent) SDs are that of
Dermestes domesticus Linnaeus
in Desmarest (1860 -273) and that of
B. lineatus
in Lacordaire (1866 -378).
Remarks: Not present in Wood and Bright (1992 -632).

Remarks: Name absent from Neave and from Wood and Bright (1992) . Available but permanently invalid because of objective synonymy with
Trypodendron
.
Remarks: Not present in Neave and Wood and Bright (1992 -632).
